name: walnut tree
description: A massive tree belonging to the 'Juglans' genus.  If you look closely, you can see some unharvested walnuts.

name: walnut tree
description: A massive tree belonging to the 'Juglans' genus.

name: butternut tree
description: A massive tree belonging to the 'Juglans' genus, but with lighter bark and more elongated fruits than the more common black walnut.  If you look closely, you can see some unharvested butternuts.

name: butternut tree
description: A massive tree belonging to the 'Juglans' genus, but with lighter bark and more elongated fruits than the more common black walnut.

name: blackjack oak
description: A deciduous tree of the genus 'Quercus', with bark cracked into rectangular black plates split by narrow orange fissures.  You could peel off the bark sections if you examined the tree more closely.
A deciduous tree of the genus 'Quercus', with bark cracked into rectangular black plates split by narrow orange fissures.  All the usable bark has been stripped off.
name: blackjack oak
alder tree
description: A deciduous flowering tree with serrated, scalloped, round-obovate leaves, commonly forming dense groves alongside water.

name: alder tree
description: A deciduous flowering tree with serrated, scalloped, round-obovate leaves, commonly forming dense groves alongside water.

name: chestnut tree
description: A massive tree belonging to the 'Castanea' genus.  If you look closely, you can see some unharvested chestnuts.

name: chestnut tree
description: A massive tree belonging to the 'Castanea' genus.

name: beech tree
description: A massive tree belonging to the 'Fagus' genus.  If you look closely, you can see some unharvested beech nuts.

name: beech tree
description: A massive tree belonging to the 'Fagus' genus.

name: hazelnut tree
description: A stubby tree belonging to the 'Corylus' genus.  If you look closely, you can see some unharvested hazelnuts.

name: hazelnut tree
description: A stubby tree belonging to the 'Corylus' genus.

name: oak tree
description: A massive deciduous tree belonging to the 'Quercus' genus, commonly found throughout the New England region.  If you look closely, you can see some acorns the squirrels haven't gotten yet.
//: barren in winter

name: oak tree
description: A massive deciduous tree belonging to the 'Quercus' genus, commonly found throughout the New England region.

name: basswood tree
description: The American linden.  It has pretty and sweet-smelling flowers in the summer, and you might be able to eat its young leaves in the spring.

name: basswood tree
description: The American linden.  It has pretty and sweet-smelling flowers in the summer, and its edible young leaves have already been harvested.

name: cottonwood tree
description: A large tree belonging to the 'Populus' genus, commonly found throughout the New England region.  You see some cottonwood tree bolls that can be harvested.
//: Do something cool with this and have it spread cotton around the area or something.

name: cottonwood tree
description: A large tree belonging to the 'Populus' genus, commonly found throughout the New England region.  All the cottonwood tree bolls have been harvested.
//: Do something cool with this and have it spread cotton around the area or something.

name: elm tree
description: A large tree belonging to the 'Ulmus' genus, commonly found throughout the New England region.

name: dead tree
description: An indiscernible tree that has withered away due to weather, fire, or otherworldly causes.
//: gives a maximum of ~15L and ~8.5kg of wood between sticks and twigs
we must avoid copy-from here so that the dead tree cannot regrow and be harvested again
name: dead tree
description: An indiscernible tree that has withered away due to weather, fire, or otherworldly causes.  Someone or something has broken most of its dead branches, leaving little but its gnarled trunk.

name: warped dead tree
description: This deciduous tree's branches are warped into a spiral.  This appears to have killed it.

name: young tree
description: A relatively young sapling of an indeterminate species.  It could take decades before reaching maturity, so there's no use waiting around.
//: barren in winter

name: mega fern
description: A gigantic fern like nothing you've seen before.  The leaves are a bright scarlet with a net-like structure of green veins.  The multipronged trunks have the texture of balsa wood.
//: barren in winter

name: apple tree
description: This tree is a member of the 'Malus' genus, producing fruit commonly known as apples.  If you examined the branches more closely, you could probably find a few mature ones in autumn.
//: barren in winter, fruits in autumn

name: apple tree
description: This tree is a member of the 'Malus' genus, producing fruit commonly known as apples.  There do not appear to be any ripe apples now.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: pear tree
description: This is 'Pyrus communis', or the common pear tree, which produces fruit in the fall.  If you examined the branches more closely, you could probably find a few mature ones.
//: barren in winter, fruits in autumn

name: pear tree
description: This is 'Pyrus communis', or the common pear tree, which produces fruit in the fall.  Looks like all the ripe pears have been picked.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: coffee tree
description: This is 'gymnocladus dioicus', or the kentucky coffee tree, which produces roastable coffee pods and brewable leaves in the fall.  If you examined the branches more closely, you could probably find a few mature ones.
//: barren in winter, fruits in autumn

name: coffee tree
description: This is 'gymnocladus dioicus', or the kentucky coffee tree, which produces roastable coffee pods and brewable leaves in the fall.  Looks like all the ripe pods have been picked.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: cherry tree
description: One of the several species of 'Prunus' trees found in New England, it bears cherries in the summer.  If you examined the foliage more closely, you could probably find some viable clusters.
//: barren in winter, fruits in summer

name: cherry tree
description: One of the several species of 'Prunus' trees found in New England, it bears cherries in the summer.  Looks like all the ripe bunches of cherries have been picked.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: juniper tree
description: One of the species of 'Juniperus' that grows in New England, juniper berries grow over two to three years.  It flowers in the first year, produces a green berry the second, and in the third produces the more famed blue varieties.  If you examined the foliage more closely, you could probably find some viable clusters.
//: Can be picked at any point in the third year assuming the berries have turned blue. But it takes a long time to regrow.

name: juniper tree
description: One of the species of 'Juniperus' that grows in New England, juniper berries grow over two to three years.  It flowers in the first year, produces a green berry the second, and in the third produces the more famed blue varieties.  Looks like all the ripe bunches of berries have been picked.
//: Will take three years to regrow, in reality.

name: peach tree
description: One of the several species of 'Prunus' trees found in New England, it bears peaches in the summer.  If you examined the branches more closely, you could probably find some mature peaches.
//: barren in winter, fruits in summer

name: peach tree
description: One of the several species of 'Prunus' trees found in New England, it bears peaches in the summer.  Looks like all the ripe peaches have been picked.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: apricot tree
description: A transplanted species of 'Prunus armeniaca', rarely found in New England.  It produces apricots in the summer.  If you examined the spurs more closely, you could probably find some mature apricots.
//: barren in winter, fruits in summer

name: apricot tree
description: A transplanted species of 'Prunus armeniaca', rarely found in New England.  It produces apricots in the summer.  Looks like all the ripe apricots have been picked.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: plum tree
description: One of the several species of 'Prunus' trees found in New England, it produces plums in the summer.  If you examined the spurs more closely, you could probably find some ripe plums.
//: barren in winter, fruits in summer

name: plum tree
description: One of the several species of 'Prunus' trees found in New England, it produces plums in the summer.  Looks like all the ripe plums have been picked.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: mulberry tree
description: This tree is a member of the 'Morus' genus, producing fruit commonly known as mulberries.  In the summer, many berries can be picked.
//: barren in winter, fruits in summer

name: mulberry tree
description: This tree is a member of the 'Morus' genus, producing fruit commonly known as mulberries.  There do not appear to be any ripe mulberries now.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: elderberry tree
description: This tree is a member of the 'Sambucus' genus, producing fruit commonly known as elderberries.  In the summer, many berries can be picked.
//: barren in winter, fruits in summer

name: elderberry tree
description: This tree is a member of the 'Sambucus' genus, producing fruit commonly known as elderberries.  There do not appear to be any ripe elderberries now.
//: barren in winter, no fruits anymore

name: pine tree
description: A towering coniferous tree that belongs to the 'Pinus' genus, with the New England species varying from 'P. strobus', 'P. resinosa' and 'P. rigida'.  If you examined the tree more closely, you might find usable sticky whorls, resin clumps, and pinecones.

name: pine tree
description: A towering coniferous tree that belongs to the 'Pinus' genus, with the New England species varying from 'P. strobus', 'P. resinosa' and 'P. rigida'.  Some of the branches and resin clumps have been stripped away and many of the pinecones aren't developed fully yet, but given a season, it could be harvestable again.

name: dead pine tree
description: A towering coniferous tree that belongs to the 'Pinus' genus, with the New England species varying from 'P. strobus', 'P. resinosa' and 'P. rigida'.  This tree's branches are bare, and it appears to be dead.

name: warped dead pine tree
description: The branches of this pine tree have been twisted into a shape that remind you of Sierpinski triangles.  It did not survive being warped like this.

name: birch tree
description: A tall deciduous tree of the 'Betula' genus, with the characteristic peeling bark.  Species like 'B. alleghaniensis', 'B. papyrifera', and 'B. populifolia' are the most common in the New England region.  You could tear off some strips of bark if you examined the tree more closely.
//: barren in winter, harvestable all year round

name: birch tree
description: A tall deciduous tree of the 'Betula' genus, with the characteristic peeling bark.  Species like 'B. alleghaniensis', 'B. papyrifera', and 'B. populifolia' are the most common in the New England region.  Looks like there isn't enough rhytidome to peel off yet.
//: dead, not harvestable

name: willow tree
description: A tall, wide deciduous tree of the 'Salix' genus, with long, thin, leafy branches that hang down like curtains.  You could tear off some bark.
//: barren in winter, harvestable all year round

name: willow tree
description: A tall, wide deciduous tree of the 'Salix' genus, with long, thin, leafy branches that hang down like curtains.  Looks like all usable bark has been torn off, and new rhytidomes have not formed yet.
//: barren in winter, not harvestable

name: maple tree
description: A large deciduous tree of the 'Acer' genus.  The leaves are distinctively shaped with five prongs.  It could be tapped in order to extract maple sap.

name: maple tree
description: A large deciduous tree of the 'Acer' genus.  The leaves are distinctively shaped with five prongs.  A spigot is wedged into the trunk, and sweet maple sap can be extracted.

name: hickory tree
description: A tall deciduous tree of the 'Carya' genus.  You could look for hickory nuts if you examined the tree more closely.
//: barren in winter, harvestable in autumn

description: A tall deciduous tree of the 'Carya' genus.  It looks like the tree has been picked clean of hickory nuts.
name: hickory tree
//: barren in winter, kind of harvestable

name: pistachio tree
description: A deciduous tree of the 'Pistacia' genus.  This is a cultivated tree, and is not native to this region.  You could look for pistachio nuts if you examined the tree more closely.
//: Pistachio tree is not a local native and is only used in specific locations like orchards and gardens.

name: pistachio tree
description: A deciduous tree of the 'Pistacia' genus.  This is a cultivated tree, and is not native to this region.  Unfortunately, it looks like it has been picked clean of pistachio nuts.

name: almond tree
description: A deciduous tree of the 'Prunus' genus.  This is a cultivated tree, and is not native to this region.  You could look for fresh almonds if you examined the tree more closely.
//: Almond tree is not a local native and is only used in specific locations like orchards and gardens.

description: A deciduous tree of the 'Prunus' genus.  This is a cultivated tree, and is not native to this region.  There are no almonds left to pick on the tree.
name: almond tree
pecan tree
description: A tall deciduous tree of the 'Carya' genus.  You could look for pecan nuts if you examined the tree more closely.
//: Pecan tree is not a local native and is only used in specific locations like orchards and gardens.

name: pecan tree
description: A tall deciduous tree of the 'Carya' genus.  It doesn't look like there are any pecan nuts left on the tree.

name: dead hickory tree
description: The dead remnants of a tall deciduous tree of the 'Carya' genus.  Nothing useful can be foraged from this poor, dead tree.
//: dead, not usable at all

name: sassafras tree
description: This tree is a member of the 'Sassafras' genus, known for its aromatic qualities.  In the winter and spring, the sap rich roots can be harvested to make a sweet beverage.

name: sassafras tree
description: This tree is a member of the 'Sassafras' genus, known for its aromatic qualities.  This tree's roots have been harvested, any more and the tree will die.
//: Cannot be harvested

name: underbrush
description: Small plants and shrubs that decorate the forest.  An observant forager could obtain edible plants, acorns, eggs, and mushrooms from it.

name: underbrush
description: Small plants and shrubs that decorate the forest.  It has been rummaged through and doesn't have anything useful left to forage from it.

name: underbrush
description: Small plants and shrubs that decorate the forest.  It has been rummaged through and doesn't have anything useful left to forage from it.

name: underbrush
description: Small plants and shrubs that decorate the forest.  It has been rummaged through and doesn't have anything useful left to forage from it.

name: underbrush
description: Small plants and shrubs that decorate the forest.  It has been rummaged through and doesn't have anything useful left to forage from it.  Frost covers it.

name: bee hive
description: A hive of bees located in a cavity inside a tree, swarming in and out at a feverish pace.  There's probably honey inside.

name: apiary
description: A man-made wooden box designed to hold honeybees and facilitate the care for a hive.  The modular construction allows for inspecting the bees and harvesting their bounty without destroying the hive completely.  This year's harvest should be ready by now.

name: apiary
description: A man-made wooden box designed to host honeybees and facilitate the care for a hive.  The modular construction allows for inspecting the bees and harvesting their bounty without destroying the hive completely.  It will be some time before this one is ready to harvest.

name: shrub
description: A small shrub.

name: peanut bush
description: A small bush of crunchy peanuts.
//: Peanut bushes are not a local native so this is for use in specific locations like farms and gardens.

name: peanut bush
description: A small peanut bush that's fruitless.

name: blueberry bush
description: A small bush of sweet blueberries.

name: blueberry bush
description: A small blueberry bush that's fruitless.

name: strawberry bush
description: A small bush of juicy strawberries.

name: strawberry bush
description: A small strawberry bush that's fruitless.

name: blackberry bush
description: A small bush of delicious blackberries.  Watch out for its thorns!

name: blackberry bush
description: A small blackberry bush that's fruitless.  Watch out for its thorns!

name: huckleberry bush
description: A small bush of huckleberries, often mistaken for blueberries.

name: huckleberry bush
description: A small huckleberry bush that's fruitless.

name: raspberry bush
description: A small bush of delicious raspberries.  Watch out for its thorns!

name: raspberry bush
description: A small raspberry bush that's fruitless.  Watch out for its thorns!

name: grape bush
description: A bush of a different species invaded by grape vines.

name: grape bush
description: A bush of a different species invaded by grape vines, but they're fruitless.

name: rose bush
description: A fat bush of beautiful red roses, if only you could get a date!  Watch out for its thorns!
//: Insert rose (flower) harvest in summer once flowers have a use (same for other generic flowers).

name: rose bush
description: A fat rose bush that currently has no blooms.  Watch out for its thorns!

name: hydrangea bush
description: A dense bush of fragrant blue hydrangeas.

name: hydrangea bush
description: A fat hydrangea bush that currently has no blooms.

name: lilac bush
description: A wide bush of bright pinkish-purple lilacs.

name: lilac bush
description: A wide lilac bush that currently has no blooms.

name: tree trunk
description: A section of trunk from a tree that has been cut down.  Can be sawn into logs with the right tool.

name: tree stump
description: A tree stump, a remnant of a tree that has been cut down.

bash.//: Tree trunks sometimes may have shoots growing on them (coppicing)

name: woodchips
description: Small splinters of wood laid out in a layer to prevent unwanted plants from growing.

name: moss
description: A patch of moist, spongy moss.

name: grass
description: An area of hardy Kentucky bluegrass about ankle high.  Cutting the grass short enough would destroy the root system, causing this area to turn into a patch of dirt.

name: white grass
description: An area of Kentucky bluegrass covered in white latex-based paint, with neat lines designed for recreational sports.

name: long grass
description: An area of long, shaggy grass about shin high.

name: tall grass
description: An area of tall grass about head high.

name: dead grass
description: An area of long, shaggy grass that hasn't been cut recently.

name: golf green
description: An area of grass mowed very short and neat.

name: alien grass
description: An area of something that almost looks like grass.  The blades are serrated and move on their own.

name: golf hole
description: A small plastic cup embedded in an area of very short, neat grass.

name: young bamboo shoots
description: An area of young bamboo shoots about ankle high.  Many shoots are just barely pushing above the ground.

name: young bamboo shoots
description: An area of young bamboo shoots about ankle high.  The smallest shoots have already been harvested.

name: long bamboo shoots
description: An area of long bamboo shoots about shin high.

name: tall bamboo
description: A tall bamboo thicket about head high.

name: dead bamboo
description: An area of long, brown, dead bamboo shoots covered in white fungus.

name: fern
description: A short plant with thousands of leaves which grow in a fractal pattern from the stem.

name: fern
description: A short plant with thousands of leaves which grow in a fractal pattern.  All of the curled shoots have been harvested.

name: mushroom colony
description: A large pile of organic matter which has molded over with fungus.  The caps of many mundane mushrooms spring from the top, you can even recognise some.  The fungi growing here don't seem edible, though.
